column1: Other
column2: Sandra, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: My mother-in-law started taking this because she started having severe pains in her shoulder, arm and thumb.  She had to wait a week to see a Dr. and was in much pain so she took her husband's Arthrotec that he used occasionally for gout flare-ups.  When she saw the Dr. she told them that this medication was helping with her severe pains.  So the Dr. went ahead and prescribed it to her and made her an appt. to see a specialist for bone pain. After a month or so, a specialist found that all the pain was due to a deficiency in vitamin K and she didn't have the arthritis.  Tests also revealed that her kidneys were failing and thought to be the result of taking Arthrotec for an extended period of time.  He took her off this medication immediately.  He believed that her kidneys may bounce back 3 to 6 months after being off of it.  A couple months into it and she started having nausea and other sick symptoms.  Went back to specialist at 3 months, nothing had changed.  He said wait at least 3 more months to see if any changes happened.  Here just shy of the total 6 months another primary Dr. tested her again because of her sickness symptoms and found that her kidneys are working at only 9%.  She has to start dialysis immediately, three times a week.  It is not known if she had any kidney disease before she started the Arthrotec, or if this medication was the cause of it.  Either way, she shouldn't have been taking it to begin with.

column1: Other
column2: seagate5, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Physician prescribed arthrotec +/- ten days ago, addressing continued lower back pain, at five (5) months post surgical L1 - L5 Laminectomy (disc and nerve impingement). It is difficult to state whether the medication has been effective for the symptoms described. After what can only be described as less than a pleasant recovery, what still remains is 'nerve pain,' centered at the rear of upper right leg, identified to be scar tissue. In any event, it renders me imobile and interferes with sleeping patterns. Despite aggressive rehab, I have not been able to extinguish problem. Aside from the items described above, I have observed a retention of water in my ankle and feet, which does concern me. I currently take Valturna (BP meds) 1x/day, effectively controlling mild upward blood pressure levels.  Is it alarmist or reluctant to resume dosages prescribed, due to the swelling. I am pleased to obseerve that other users of ARTHROTEC have found benefits that satisfy the intent for which it was prescribed.  While the literature does mention hand/feet swelling in a precautionary statement under the SIDE EFFECT CATEGORY, it is not very high on the list. I am curious whether other users have experienced similar symptoms. Good luck to all
